repnme.cdata!:
India - Small and Medium Enterprise
            Financing and Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Small and Medium
            Enterprise Financing and Development Project for India were
            as follows: outcomes were satisfactory; risk to development
            outcome was negligible or low; Bank performance was
            satisfactory and borrower performance was also satisfactory.
            Some lessons learned includes: a credit line accompanied by
            a technical assistance component can contribute to a more
            comprehensive project design by addressing both supply side
            and demand side issues, components complemented one another
            and led to effective synergy and improved outcomes. The
            establishment of an autonomous Project Management Division
            (PMD) right at the start of the project ensured
            uninterrupted and seamless implementation of the project,
            and facilitated successful project implementation.
            Countercyclical funding to viable businesses can be an
            effective post-crisis measure, not just in terms of
            providing funding but also the 'signaling effect'.
            Expansion of project activities in low income states can be
            greatly facilitated by a strategy that relies on identifying
            appropriate existing financial intermediaries with local
            presence and providing them adequate support. Strong
            commitment and ownership, good technical and human resource
            capacity, proactive approach for resolving implementation
            issues; advance planning for disbursements and competent
            staff on the part of the client, and close coordination with
            the donors, are important for the smooth implementation and
            achievement of the project objectives

17924077.theme: Micro, Small and Medium Enterprise support
17924077.trustfund:
TF051484-UK-DFID AND WORLD BANK
            PARTNERSHIP FOR INDIA - SACIA

repnme.cdata!:
India - Additional Financing for the Small
            and Medium Enterprise Financing and Development Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Additional
            Financing for the Small and Medium Enterprise (SME)
            Financing and Development Project is to improve SME access
            to finance (particularly longer term financing) and business
            development services, thereby fostering SME growth,
            competitiveness and employment creation, which are key to
            achieving Government of India's (GoI's) overall
            objectives of economic growth and poverty reduction. The
            main reason for seeking this reallocation is that further
            Government budgeting will not materialize before the
            project's extended closing date-a prerequisite for
            further utilization of the Risk Sharing Facility (RSF). The
            reallocation to the Credit Facility (CF) will expand the
            coverage of SMEs under the project. A reallocation of
            project proceeds from the RSF to the CF, in the amount of
            8.57 million US dollar. This will allow the full project
            proceeds to be utilized. The achievement of Project
            Development Objectives (PDOs) pursuant to the proposed
            change in allocation of project proceeds will not be affected.

display_title.display_title:
India - Additional Financing for
            the Small and Medium Enterprise Financing and Development
            Project : restructuring : Main report

17040419.theme: Micro, Small and Medium Enterprise support
17040419.trustfund:
TF051484-UK-DFID AND WORLD BANK
            PARTNERSHIP FOR INDIA - SACIA

repnme.cdata!:
India - Additional Financing for the Small
            and Medium Enterprise Financing and Development Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Additional
            Financing for the Small and Medium Enterprise (SME)
            Financing and Development Project is to improve SME access
            to finance (particularly longer term financing) and business
            development services, thereby fostering SME growth,
            competitiveness and employment creation, which are key to
            achieving Government of India's (GoI's) overall
            objectives of economic growth and poverty reduction. The
            closing date of the project will be extended from June 30,
            2012 to June 30, 2013.The main reason for seeking an
            extension of the closing date is to allow for time to
            implement the risk sharing facility of the project, which
            had been delayed on primarily on account of lack of
            budgeting, a factor outside of Small Industries Development
            Bank of India's (SIDBI's) control. Extension would
            allow the Bank team to continue to oversee and provide
            technical inputs on what is a particularly innovative
            component of the project, the Risk Sharing Facility (RSF).
            Extension will also allow SIDBI to channel the originally
            unallocated amount of US$ 9 million through further
            refinancing under the Credit Facility (CF), hence expanding
            the project's demonstration effect. In addition, a side
            benefit is that an extended project time period would allow
            for supporting greater dissemination of the project's
            Environment and Social Safeguards Framework (ESMF) to the
            banking system, a process that has been gained momentum
            recently, with strong initial results.

display_title.display_title:
India - Additional Financing for
            the Small and Medium Enterprise Financing and Development
            Project : restructuring (Vol. 2) : Data sheet
